TEXT: CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . On DATE CARDINAL commercial aeroplanes were hijacked over GPE . CARDINAL of them were flown directly at FAC of ORG and a third at the ORG , causing great loss of life and destruction to property . The NORP extremist terrorist organisation ORG , led by PERSON , claimed responsibility . GPE joined with GPE in military action in GPE , which had been used as a base for ORG training camps .

CARDINAL . The Government contended that the events of DATE demonstrated that international terrorists , notably those associated with ORG , had the intention and capacity to mount attacks against civilian targets on an unprecedented scale . Further , given the loose - knit , global structure of ORG and its affiliates and their fanaticism , ruthlessness and determination , it would be difficult for the ORG to prevent future attacks . In the ORG ’s assessment , GPE , because of its close links with GPE , was a particular target . They considered that there was an emergency of a most serious kind threatening the life of the nation . Moreover , they considered that the threat came principally , but not exclusively , from a number of foreign nationals present in GPE , who were providing a support network for NORP terrorist operations linked to ORG . A number of these foreign nationals could not be deported because of the risk that they would suffer treatment contrary to LAW in their countries of origin .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Secretary of ORG made a derogation order under LAW DATE ( “ the DATE ” – see paragraph CARDINAL below ) in which he set out the terms of a proposed notification to the Secretary General of ORG of a derogation pursuant to LAW . On DATE the Government lodged the derogation with the Secretary General of ORG . The derogation notice provided as follows :
“ Public emergency in GPE

The terrorist attacks in GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE on DATE resulted in CARDINAL deaths , including many NORP victims and others from CARDINAL different countries . In its Resolutions CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and DATE ( DATE ) , ORG recognised the attacks as a threat to international peace and security .

The threat from international terrorism is a continuing one . In its Resolution CARDINAL ( DATE ) , ORG , acting under LAW , required all GPE to take measures to prevent the commission of terrorist attacks , including by denying safe haven to those who finance , plan , support or commit terrorist attacks .

There exists a terrorist threat to GPE from persons suspected of involvement in international terrorism . In particular , there are foreign nationals present in GPE who are suspected of being concerned in the commission , preparation or instigation of acts of international terrorism , of being members of organisations or groups which are so concerned or of having links with members of such organisations or groups , and who are a threat to the national security of GPE .
As a result , a public emergency , within the meaning of LAW , exists in GPE .
The Anti - terrorism , Crime and Security Act DATE

As a result of the public emergency , provision is made in the LAW - terrorism , LAW DATE , inter alia , for an extended power to arrest and detain a foreign national which will apply where it is intended to remove or deport the person from GPE but where removal or deportation is not for the time being possible , with the consequence that the detention would be unlawful under existing domesticlaw powers . The extended power to arrest and detain will apply where the Secretary of ORG issues a certificate indicating his belief that the person ’s presence in GPE is a risk to national security and that he suspects the person of being an international terrorist . That certificate will be subject to an appeal to ORG ( ‘ PERSON ) , established under ORG Act DATE , which will have power to cancel it if it considers that the certificate should not have been issued . There will be an appeal on a point of law from a ruling by ORG . In addition , the certificate will be reviewed by ORG at regular intervals . ORG will also be able to grant bail , where appropriate , subject to conditions . It will be open to a detainee to end his detention at any time by agreeing to leave GPE .

The extended power of arrest and detention in the Anti - terrorism , Crime and Security Act DATE is a measure which is strictly required by the exigencies of the situation . It is a temporary provision which comes into force for an initial period of DATE and then expires unless renewed by ORG . Thereafter , it is subject to DATE renewal by ORG . If , at any time , in the ORG ’s assessment , the public emergency no longer exists or the extended power is no longer strictly required by the exigencies of the situation , then the Secretary of ORG will , by order , repeal the provision .
Domestic - law powers of detention ( other than under the Anti - terrorism , Crime and Security Act DATE )

The Government has powers under LAW DATE ( ‘ the DATE Act’ ) to remove or deport persons on the ground that their presence in GPE is not conducive to the public good on national security grounds . Persons can also be arrested and detained under LAW and DATE to the DATE LAW pending their removal or deportation . The courts in GPE have ruled that this power of detention can only be exercised during the period necessary , in all the circumstances of the particular case , to effect removal and that , if it becomes clear that removal is not going to be possible within a reasonable time , detention will be unlawful ( NORP v. Governor of ORG , ex parte PERSON [ DATE ] All ER CARDINAL ) .
LAW ( f ) of the Convention

It is well established that LAW ( f ) permits the detention of a person with a view to deportation only in circumstances where ‘ action is being taken with a view to GPE ( PERSON v. GPE ( DATE ) CARDINAL EHRR CARDINAL at paragraph CARDINAL ) . In that case ORG indicated that detention will cease to be permissible under LAW ( f ) if deportation proceedings are not prosecuted with due diligence and that it was necessary in such cases to determine whether the duration of the deportation proceedings was excessive ( paragraph CARDINAL ) .

In some cases , where the intention remains to remove or deport a person on national security grounds , continued detention may not be consistent with LAW ( f ) as interpreted by ORG in the PERSON case . This may be the case , for example , if the person has established that removal to their own country might result in treatment contrary to LAW . In such circumstances , irrespective of the gravity of the threat to national security posed by the person concerned , it is well established that LAW prevents removal or deportation to a place where there is a real risk that the person will suffer treatment contrary to that Article . If no alternative destination is immediately available then removal or deportation may not , for the time being , be possible even though the ultimate intention remains to remove or deport the person once satisfactory arrangements can be made . In addition , it may not be possible to prosecute the person for a criminal offence given the strict rules on the admissibility of evidence in the criminal justice system of GPE and the high standard of proof required .
Derogation under LAW

The Government has considered whether the exercise of the extended power to detain contained in the Anti - terrorism , Crime and Security Act DATE may be inconsistent with the obligations under LAW . As indicated above , there may be cases where , notwithstanding a continuing intention to remove or deport a person who is being detained , it is not possible to say that ‘ action is being taken with a view to GPE within the meaning of LAW ( f ) as interpreted by ORG in the PERSON case . To the extent , therefore , that the exercise of the extended power may be inconsistent with GPE obligations under LAW , the ORG has decided to avail itself of the right of derogation conferred by LAW and will continue to do so until further notice . ”
The derogation notice then set out the provisions of Part CARDINAL of the Anti - terrorism , Crime and Security Bill CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Anti - terrorism , Crime and Security Bill , containing the clauses which were to eventually become Part CARDINAL of the Anti - terrorism , Crime and Security Act DATE ( “ the DATE LAW see paragraph DATE below ) , was introduced into ORG . The PERSON was passed by ORG in DATE , with DATE of debate on the floor of ORG set aside for its CARDINAL clauses in a restrictive programming motion , prompting both ORG and the Home Affairs Select Committee to complain of the speed with which they were being asked to consider the matter .

CARDINAL . The DATE Act came into force on DATE . During the lifetime of the legislation , QUANTITY individuals , including the present CARDINAL applicants , were certified under LAW and detained . The first CARDINAL applicants were certified on DATE and taken into detention shortly thereafter . The seventh applicant was certified and detained in DATE ; the ninth applicant on DATE ; the eighth applicant on DATE ; the tenth applicant on DATE ; and the eleventh applicant was certified on DATE and kept in detention , having previously been held under other legislation .

CARDINAL . NORP In proceedings before ORG ( DATE see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) , the first CARDINAL applicants challenged the legality of the derogation , claiming that their detention under LAW was in breach of their rights under LAW , DATE , DATE and CARDINAL of the Convention . Each , in addition , challenged the Secretary of ORG ’s decision to certify him as an international terrorist .

CARDINAL . On DATE , having examined both open and closed material and heard submissions from special advocates in addition to counsel for the parties and for the third party , ORG , ORG delivered its ruling on the legality of the derogation . It held that , on the basis of the open material , it was satisfied that the threat from ORG had created a public emergency threatening the life of the nation , within the meaning of LAW , and that the closed material confirmed this view .

ORG further held that the fact that the objective of protecting the public from international terrorists could possibly have been achieved by alternative methods did not demonstrate that the measures actually adopted were not strictly necessary . Moreover , since the purpose of the detention was the protection of GPE , the fact that the detainee was at liberty to leave demonstrated that the measures were properly tailored to the state of emergency .

ORG rejected the ORG complaints under LAW . It held that , in so far as they related to conditions of detention , the applicants should bring proceedings in the ordinary civil courts , and that ORG had no jurisdiction to determine such a complaint as it was not a “ derogation issue ” . It further saw no merit in the applicants’ argument that detention for an indefinite period was contrary to LAW . On this point , ORG held that the detention was not indefinite , since it was governed by the time - limits of the CARDINAL LAW itself and since the DATE Act provided that each applicant ’s certification was subject to automatic review by ORG DATE . In any event , the mere fact that no term had yet been fixed for preventive detention did not give rise to a breach of LAW .

ORG did not accept that LAW applied to the certification process . The certification of each applicant as a suspected international terrorist was not a “ charge ” but instead a statement of suspicion and the proceedings before ORG were not for the determination of a criminal charge . Furthermore , there was no relevant civil right at issue and LAW did not apply in its civil limb either .

ORG did , however , rule that the derogation was unlawful because the relevant provisions of the DATE Act unjustifiably discriminated against foreign nationals , in breach of LAW . The powers of LAW could properly be confined to non - nationals only if the threat stemmed exclusively , or almost exclusively , from non - nationals and the evidence did not support that conclusion . In paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL of its judgment , ORG held :

“ CARDINAL . If there is to be an effective derogation from the right to liberty enshrined in DATE in respect of suspected international terrorists – and we can see powerful arguments in favour of such a derogation – the derogation ought rationally to extend to all irremovable suspected international terrorists . It would properly be confined to the alien section of the population only if , as [ counsel for the appellants ] contends , the threat stems exclusively or almost exclusively from that alien section .

CARDINAL . But the evidence before us demonstrates beyond argument that the threat is not so confined . There are many NORP nationals already identified – mostly in detention abroad – who fall within the definition of ‘ suspected international ORG , and it was clear from the submissions made to us that in the opinion of the [ Secretary of ORG ] there are others at liberty in GPE who could be similarly defined . In those circumstances we fail to see how the derogation can be regarded as other than discriminatory on the grounds of national origin . ”
ORG thus quashed the derogation order of DATE and issued a declaration of incompatibility in respect of LAW under section CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

It adjourned the first CARDINAL ORG individual appeals against certification ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) pending the outcome of the Secretary of ORG ’s appeal and the applicants’ cross - appeal on points of law against the above ruling .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG delivered its judgment ( NORP and Others v. Secretary of ORG for ORG [ DATE ] EWCA Civ CARDINAL ) .

It held that ORG had been entitled to find that there was a public emergency threatening the life of the nation . However , contrary to the view of ORG , it held that the approach adopted by the Secretary of ORG could be objectively justified . There was a rational connection between the detention of non - nationals who could not be deported because of fears for their safety , and the purpose which the Secretary of ORG wished to achieve , which was to remove non - nationals who posed a threat to national security . Moreover , the applicants would be detained for no longer than was necessary before they could be deported or until the emergency was resolved or they ceased to be a threat to the country ’s safety . There was no discrimination contrary to LAW , because NORP nationals suspected of being terrorists were not in an analogous situation to similarly suspected foreign nationals who could not be deported because of fears for their safety . Such foreign nationals did not have a right to remain in the country but only a right , for the time being , not to be removed for their own safety . ORG added that it was well established in international law that , in some situations , GPE could distinguish between nationals and non - nationals , especially in times of emergency . It further concluded that ORG had been entitled to limit the measures proposed so as to affect only foreign nationals suspected of terrorist links because it was entitled to reach the conclusion that detention of only the limited class of foreign nationals with which the measures were concerned was , in the circumstances , “ strictly required ” within the meaning of LAW .

ORG agreed with ORG that the proceedings to appeal against certification were not “ criminal ” within the meaning of LAW . It found , however , that the civil limb of LAW applied but that the proceedings were as fair as could reasonably be achieved . It further held that the applicants had not demonstrated that their detention amounted to a breach of LAW .
CARDINAL . The applicants were granted leave to appeal to ORG , which delivered its judgment on DATE ( [ DATE ] ORG CARDINAL ) .

A majority of ORG , expressly or impliedly , found that the applicants’ detention DATE Act did not fall within the exception to the general right of liberty set out in LAW ( f ) of LAW ( see Lord PERSON , at paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL ; Lord PERSON , at paragraph CARDINAL ; Lord Hope , at paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL ; Lord PERSON , at paragraph CARDINAL ; Lord PERSON , at paragraph CARDINAL ; ORG , at paragraph CARDINAL ) . Lord PERSON summarised the position in this way :

“ CARDINAL . ... A person who commits a serious crime under the criminal law of this country may of course , whether a national or a non - national , be charged , tried and , if convicted , imprisoned . But a non - national who faces the prospect of torture or inhuman treatment if returned to his own country , and who can not be deported to any third country , and is not charged with any crime , may not under LAW ( f ) of LAW to LAW DATE be detained here even if judged to be a threat to national security . ”

CARDINAL . ORG further held , by CARDINAL ( ORG and PERSON with considerable hesitation ) , that ORG ’s conclusion that there was a public emergency threatening the life of the nation should not be displaced . Lord Hope assessed the evidence as follows :

“ CARDINAL . There is ample evidence within [ the open ] material to show that the government were fully justified in taking the view in DATE that there was an emergency threatening the life of the nation . ... [ The ] GPE was at danger of attacks from the ORG network which had the capacity through its associates to inflict massive casualties and have a devastating effect on the functioning of the nation . This had been demonstrated by the events of DATE in GPE , GPE and GPE . There was a significant body of foreign nationals in GPE who had the will and the capability of mounting coordinated attacks here which would be just as destructive to human life and to property . There was ample intelligence to show that international terrorist organisations involved in recent attacks and in preparation for other attacks of terrorism had links with GPE , and that they and others posed a continuing threat to this country . There was a growing body of evidence showing preparations made for the use of weapons of mass destruction in this campaign . ... [ It ] was considered [ by ORG ] that the serious threats to the nation emanated predominantly , albeit not exclusively , and more immediately from the category of foreign nationals .

CARDINAL . The picture which emerges clearly from these statements is of a current state of emergency . It is an emergency which is constituted by the threat that these attacks will be carried out . It threatens the life of the nation because of the appalling consequences that would affect us all if they were to occur here . But it can not yet be said that these attacks are imminent . On DATE the Secretary of ORG said in ORG that there was no immediate intelligence pointing to a specific threat to GPE : see ORG , col CARDINAL ) . On DATE this assessment of the position was repeated in the government ’s response to ORG of ORG on the Threat from Terrorism ( ORG CARDINAL , para CARDINAL ) where it was stated that it would be wrong to say that there was evidence of a particular threat . I would not conclude from the material which we have seen that there was no current emergency . But I would conclude that the emergency which the threats constitute is of a different kind , or on a different level , from that which would undoubtedly ensue if the threats were ever to materialise . The evidence indicates that the latter emergency can not yet be said to be imminent . It has to be recognised that , as the attacks are likely to come without warning , it may not be possible to identify a stage when they can be said to be imminent . This is an important factor , and I do not leave it out of account . But the fact is that the stage when the nation has to face that kind of emergency , the emergency of imminent attack , has not been reached . ”

Lord PERSON , who dissented , accepted that there was credible evidence of a threat of serious terrorist attack within GPE , but considered that it would not destroy the life of the nation , since the threat was not so fundamental as to threaten “ our institutions of government or our existence as a civil community ” . He concluded that “ the real threat to the life of the nation ... comes not from terrorism but from laws such as these ” .

CARDINAL . The other Law Lords ( Lords GPE , PERSON , Hope , PERSON , PERSON , ORG and ORG , with Lord PERSON dissenting ) rejected the ORG ’s submission that it was for ORG and the executive , rather than the courts , to judge the response necessary to protect the security of the public . Lord PERSON expressed his view as follows :

“ DATE . It follows from this analysis that the appellants are in my opinion entitled to invite the courts to review , on proportionality grounds , the derogation order and the compatibility with the Convention of section CARDINAL [ of LAW ] and the courts are not effectively precluded by any doctrine of deference from scrutinising the issues raised . It also follows that I do not accept the full breadth of the Attorney - General ’s submissions . I do not in particular accept the distinction which he drew between democratic institutions and the courts . It is of course true that the judges in this country are not elected and are not answerable to ORG . It is also of course true ... that ORG , the executive and the courts have different functions . But the function of independent judges charged to interpret and apply the law is universally recognised as a cardinal feature of the modern democratic ORG , a cornerstone of the rule of law itself . The Attorney - General is fully entitled to insist on the proper limits of judicial authority , but he is wrong to stigmatise judicial decision - making as in some way undemocratic . It is particularly inappropriate in a case such as the present in which ORG has expressly legislated in section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act to render unlawful any act of a public authority , including a court , incompatible with a Convention right ; has required courts ( in section CARDINAL ) to take account of relevant GPE jurisprudence ; has ( in section CARDINAL ) required courts , so far as possible , to give effect to Convention rights and has conferred a right of appeal on derogation issues . The effect is not , of course , to override the sovereign legislative authority of the Queen in ORG , since if primary legislation is declared to be incompatible the validity of the legislation is unaffected ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) and the remedy lies with the appropriate minister ( section CARDINAL ) , who is answerable to ORG . LAW gives the courts a very specific , wholly democratic , mandate . ”

CARDINAL . NORP The majority therefore examined whether the detention regime under LAW was a proportionate response to the emergency situation , and concluded that it did not rationally address the threat to security and was a disproportionate response to that threat . They relied on CARDINAL principal grounds : firstly , that the detention scheme applied only to non - nationals suspected of international terrorism and did not address the threat which came from GPE nationals who were also so suspected ; secondly , that it left suspected international terrorists at liberty to leave GPE and continue their threatening activities abroad ; thirdly , that the legislation was drafted too broadly , so that it could , in principle , apply to individuals suspected of involvement with international terrorist organisations which did not fall within the scope of the derogation .

On the first point , Lord PERSON emphasised that ORG ’s finding that the terrorist threat was not confined to non - nationals had not been challenged . Since ORG was the responsible fact - finding tribunal , it was unnecessary to examine the basis for its finding , but there was evidence that “ upwards of CARDINAL individuals from the GPE are estimated on the basis of intelligence to have attended training camps in GPE in DATE ” ; that some NORP citizens were said to have planned to return from GPE to GPE ; and that the background material relating to the applicants showed the high level of involvement of NORP citizens and those otherwise connected with GPE in the terrorist networks . Lord PERSON continued :

“ CARDINAL . ... It is plain that sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the DATE Act do not address the threat presented by GPE nationals since they do not provide for the certification and detention of GPE nationals . It is beside the point that other sections of LAW and the CARDINAL Act do apply to GPE nationals , since they are not the subject of derogation , are not the subject of complaint and apply equally to foreign nationals . Yet the threat from GPE nationals , if quantitatively smaller , is not said to be qualitatively different from that from foreign nationals . It is also plain that sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL do permit a person certified and detained to leave GPE and go to any other country willing to receive him , as CARDINAL of the appellants did when they left for GPE and GPE respectively ... Such freedom to leave is wholly explicable in terms of immigration control : if the NORP authorities wish to deport a foreign national but can not deport him to country ‘ A’ because of PERSON their purpose is as well served by his voluntary departure for country ‘ B’ . But allowing a suspected international terrorist to leave our shores and depart to another country , perhaps a country as close as GPE , there to pursue his criminal designs , is hard to reconcile with a belief in his capacity to inflict serious injury to the people and interests of this country . ...

CARDINAL . The fifth step in the appellants’ argument permits of little elaboration . But it seems reasonable to assume that those suspected international terrorists who are GPE nationals are not simply ignored by the authorities . When [ the fifth applicant ] was released from prison by ORG on bail ... it was on condition ( among other things ) that he wear an electronic monitoring tag at all times ; that he remain at his premises at all times ; that he telephone a named security company CARDINAL times DATE at specified times ; that he permit the company to install monitoring equipment at his LOC ; that he limit entry to his LOC to his family , his solicitor , his medical attendants and other approved persons ; that he make no contact with any other person ; that he have on his premises no computer equipment , mobile telephone or other electronic communications device ; that he cancel the existing telephone link to his LOC ; and that he install a dedicated telephone link permitting contact only with the security company . The appellants suggested that conditions of this kind , strictly enforced , would effectively inhibit terrorist activity . It is hard to see why this would not be so .

CARDINAL . In urging the fundamental importance of the right to personal freedom , as the sixth step in their proportionality argument , the appellants were able to draw on the long libertarian tradition of LANGUAGE law , dating back to LAW of PERSON DATE , given effect in the ancient remedy of habeas corpus , declared in LAW , upheld in a series of landmark decisions down DATE and embodied in the substance and procedure of the law to our own day . ... In its treatment of LAW , ORG also has recognised the prime importance of personal freedom . ...

CARDINAL . The appellants’ proportionality challenge to the order and section CARDINAL is , in my opinion , sound , for all the reasons they gave and also for those given by the NORP Commissioner for Human Rights and ORG . The Attorney - General could give no persuasive answer . ”

CARDINAL . In addition , the majority held that the DATE Act was discriminatory and inconsistent with LAW , from which there had been no derogation . The applicants were in a comparable situation to GPE nationals suspected of being international terrorists , with whom they shared the characteristics of being irremovable from GPE and being considered a threat to national security . Since the detention scheme was aimed primarily at the protection of GPE from terrorist attack , rather than immigration control , there was no objective reason to treat the applicants differently on grounds of their nationality or immigration status .

CARDINAL . Although the ORG appeal had included complaints under LAW and QUANTITY of the LAW , ORG did not consider it necessary to determine these complaints since it had found the derogation to be unlawful on other grounds .

CARDINAL . It granted a quashing order in respect of the derogation order , and a declaration under LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) that section CARDINAL of the DATE Act was incompatible with Articles CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Convention in so far as it was disproportionate and permitted discriminatory detention of suspected international terrorists .

CARDINAL . Meanwhile , ORG ’s hearing of the applicants’ individual appeals against certification commenced in DATE , after ORG had given judgment in the derogation proceedings but before the above judgment of ORG .

CARDINAL . For the purposes of each appeal to ORG , the Secretary of ORG filed an “ open statement ” summarising the facts connected to the decision to certify each applicant and as much of the supporting evidence which the Secretary of ORG considered could be disclosed without giving rise to any risk to national security . A further , “ closed ” statement of facts and evidence was also placed before ORG in each case .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued a “ generic ” judgment in which it made a number of findings of general application to all the appeals against certification .

As regards preliminary issues , it found , inter alia , that it had jurisdiction to hear an appeal against certification even where the person certified had left GPE and the certificate had been revoked . It held that the tests whether reasonable grounds existed for suspicion that a person was a “ terrorist ” and for belief that his presence in GPE was a risk to national security , within the meaning of section DATE CARDINAL Act , fell “ some way short of proof even on the balance of probabilities ” . It further held that “ reasonable grounds could be based on material which would not be admissible in a normal trial in court , such as hearsay evidence of an unidentified informant ” . The weight that was to be attached to any particular piece of evidence was a matter for consideration in the light of all the evidence viewed as a whole . Information which might have been obtained by torture should not automatically be excluded , but the court should have regard to any evidence about the manner in which it was obtained and judge its weight and reliability accordingly .

ORG held that the detention provisions in the CARDINAL Act should be interpreted in the light of the terms of the derogation . The threat to the life of the nation was not confined to activities within GPE , because the nation ’s life included its diplomatic , cultural and tourism - related activities abroad . Moreover , attacks on GPE allies could also create a risk to GPE , given the interdependence of countries facing a global terrorist threat . The derogation identified the threat as emanating from ORG and its associates . It was therefore necessary , in respect of both the “ national security ” and the “ international terrorist ” limbs of section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act , to show reasonable grounds for suspicion that the person certified was part of a group which was connected , directly or indirectly , to ORG . Even if the main focus of the group in question was a national struggle , if it backed ORG for a part of its agenda and the individual nonetheless supported the group , it was a legitimate inference that he was supporting and assisting ORG .

ORG also made a number of findings of fact of general application concerning organisations alleged by the Secretary of ORG to be linked to ORG . These findings were based on both “ open ” and “ closed ” material . Thus , it held , for example , that ORG for Call and Combat ( GSPC ) , which was formed in GPE in DATE , was an international terrorist organisation linked to ORG through training and funding , but that the earlier NORP organisation , ORG ( ORG ) , was not . ORG ( EIJ ) was either part of ORG or very closely linked to it . The Chechen Arab Mujahaddin was an international terrorist group , pursuing an anti - West agenda beyond the struggle for NORP independence , with close links to ORG . ORG also identified as falling within the terms of the derogation a group of primarily NORP extremists centred around GPE , an NORP who had lived in GPE from DATE . It was alleged that GPE had held a senior role in training camps in GPE and had many contacts in ORG , including a connection with the GPE cell which had been accused of plotting to bomb the Strasbourg Christmas Market in DATE . PERSON was arrested in DATE , following an extradition request from GPE , but his group remained active .

CARDINAL . The applicants appealed against ORG ’s ruling that evidence which might have been obtained by torture was admissible . For the purposes of the appeal , the parties agreed that the proceedings before ORG to challenge certification fell within LAW and as such had to satisfy the basic requirements of a fair trial . It was not , therefore , necessary to decide whether LAW also applied and the issue was left open .
On DATE ORG , by a majority , upheld ORG ’s decision ( [ CARDINAL ] EWCA Civ CARDINAL ) .

On DATE ORG held unanimously that the evidence of a suspect or witness which had been obtained by torture had long been regarded as inherently unreliable , unfair , offensive to ordinary standards of humanity and decency and incompatible with the principles on which courts should administer justice . It followed that such evidence might not lawfully be admitted against a party to proceedings in a GPE court , irrespective of where , by whom and on whose authority the torture had been inflicted . Since the person challenging certification had only limited access to the material advanced against him in the proceedings before ORG , he could not be expected to do more than raise a plausible reason that material might have been so obtained and it was then for ORG to initiate the relevant enquiries . ORG therefore allowed the ORG appeals and remitted each case to ORG for reconsideration ( [ DATE ] ORG CARDINAL ) .
